text: Looking over the Beacon series...it's just so sad how bad the red one is...
So for 5 mana you do 5 damage. In black for 5 I return a creature or artifact to the field. One of these is not like the other.

I've actually created average decks on EDHREC quite a few times. It's a great starting point for a new commander. In fact, I mentioned creating an average deck in my article for Mairsil. It looked decent for a CMDR with tons of options.
lol. Yeah, the red one beacon is bad. Too many times red finishes 6th out of 5 in the cycles. :confused:

It's one of reds biggest issues with the color pie. It really needs more diversity. Because the majority of cards go through standard and red is so Burn and aggro focused, the balance for a 20 life format throws them off in Commander
It's sad
It needed more diversity. It's come a long way since the Beacon cycle.
Or the command cycle
Fiery confluence was pretty sweet though
more diversity... agreed. They are definitely giving red new options... I think Outpost Siege was a good start. And, the new red curse is groovy too
Outpost Siege might be the best addition to red edh in a decade
The red curse is pretty sweet for red to ramp
No, that's Chaos Warp
But it's up there
You don't spend that gold, you win with Hellkite tyrant with it
I thought that's what Mycosynth Lattice was for
It always feels like red tends to get boned in the prestige cycles. Beacon, Titan, Primordial, Soul, Praetor, Zenith, Command
I like Inferno Titan better than Frost Titan. TBH
And Urabrask is a pretty unique effect in red.
I agree on the titans.
Urabrask is good, it's just the others are game enders
Frost is ok but the power level is pretty low compared to the other titans.
I think I run Urabrask before I run Jin-Gitaxias
Urabrask is the most "fair" of the praetors
Yeah. I just love red doing something that bends pie.
I love it to. Seeing exile-draw become a thing is super cool, and we're seeing Wizards test a new type of land-hate that I hope they continue to push.
The red beacon could have destroyed two non-basic lands or something else in Red's world.
I'd be down for that, but it's hella mean.
The impulse draw stuff is so on-theme for red
It's genuinely interesting in that it kind of forces good deck building. If you're running a tight enough curve even [[Act on Impulse]] is playable.

attachments.text:
Sorcery
Exile the top three cards of your library. Until end of turn, you may play cards exiled this way. _(If you cast a spell this way, you still pay its costs. You can play a land this way only if you have an available land play remaining.)_
_"You don't want to know what happens after I put on the goggles."_

text: the pact cycle, red is pretty bad too
I'm not as big a fan of the ones tied to a dude. I'm sure they work in other environments but I can't imagine flamespeaker is getting through very reliably in EDH
You don't want a 4/4 giant at instant speed?
I run Flamespeaker in Grenzo, but that's because Grenzo.
I'm ok with the effect being stapled to dudes if they have some evasion. Prophetic was one of the first instances of the effect, so wizards was likely experimenting. I'm glad it exists at least.
I tend to be super ocd about theme w creatures too, so that is also a thing. It would bug me putting it in a deck for draw if it wasn't tied in with what I was doing. That's just me though.
Totally fair. I do that too.

text: we were talking about this appraoch earlier
I like how the flavor text in no way matches the art of a tired woodsman in a sleeping cap barricading the door of his shack.
The art absolutely tells a story, but it's the story of a dude taking extreme measures to insure nobody bothers him during his nap.
he’s not the worst legends legend I’ve seen
He's probably a better jund giant commander than ulrich is a werewolf commander
I like how big those boards would have to be to cover that door, that is giant sized

aren’t there those creature enchantments that pop around and kill shit?

there is a black one

text: The original exodus flavor text was a follow up to lhurgoyf's. "Not again!"

"Not again."
—Hans
*Stronghold not exodus

That Ancient Grudge text does a lot of handholding. "If there's anything a werewolf hates, it's a collar, especially Avacyn's Collar, the symbol of her church, because the church folk kill werewolves, so therefore a collar with the symbol of the people that kill them is something they really hate."
“and if there is one thing that werewolves hate, is being killed”
[[Razaketh, the Foulblooded]] was lamented for similar reasons, but its not nearly as egregious as Ancient Grudge
